executive_summary: According to the National Institute for Mental Health (NIH), in 2020, one in five adults experienced a mental illness, while one in 25 lived with a severe mental illness in the United States. While growing awareness of behavioral health treatment has encouraged individuals to seek treatment, large percentages of unmet mental health need exist in every state, disproportionately in rural areas.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Upset Then Boosted the Need for Mental Health Services
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Preexisting acute mental health conditions were made worse by COVID-19 as uncertain economic conditions, job loss, social isolation and health fears took hold. Despite a need for acute care at psychiatric hospitals, many were mandated to halt admissions, allowing emergency cases to reduce the spread of COVID-19. Relaxed COVID concerns in 2021 enabled industry facilities to treat more patients, enabling revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE GOVERNMENT'S ACTIONS SUPPORT FUNDING AND HOSPITAL RATE INCREASES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The US Department of Health & Human Services (HHS) states that more than two-thirds of mental healthcare spending is generated from government-sponsored healthcare. Inpatient psychiatric facilities received 2.3% of government payments to all hospitals in 2020. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) adjusted its Medicare payment 2022 policies and rates for the Inpatient Psychiatric Facility (IPF) Prospective Payment System (PPS) by 2.0%. This adjustment will result in a 0.1% increase in aggregate payments.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE SNOWBALL OF CONSOLIDATION MAY BRING COST SAVINGS BUT NOT WAGE RELIEF
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industries across the healthcare sector have undergone significant consolidation activity. For some hospitals, heightened regulation stemming from the Affordable Care Act encouraged acquisition activity because larger companies can more effectively pool resources, eliminate redundancies and cut costs to meet budget goals. Increased consolidation activity, in turn, encouraged merger and acquisition activity as healthcare companies sought growth to remain competitive with one another and retain bargaining power with suppliers and payers. Despite increased consolidation, a nationwide shortage of nurses and psychologists has increased wages as industry enterprises vie for critical staff.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation will increase concentration and benefit hospitals and patients
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Larger enterprises are more able to invest in medical innovations that enhance services and outcomes. A large size will confer negotiating power with insurance companies and offer benefits to attract skilled workers in a fiercely competitive labor market. Private equity enterprises will capitalize on opportunities to invest in hospital infrastructure that facilitates value-based purchasing models that allow incentivized reimbursement rates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Awareness and increased funding will lead to growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The increased awareness of mental health issues, a residual effect of COVID-19, will increase the number of individuals seeking treatment which filters down to hospital referrals. Greater per capita disposable income, lower unemployment rates leading to more people with insurance and increased Medicare and Medicaid expenditures will allow patients to better pay for expensive hospitalization.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government Policy Can Help and Hinder the Bottom Line
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Biden Administration could increase the likelihood of employee unionization. Increased funding in many areas of mental health will spur awareness at many levels in the healthcare delivery system and destigmatize treatments. While costs can be reduced with value-based purchasing models, smaller hospitals may find the switch costly, leading to reduced reimbursement rates.

industry_definition: The Psychiatric Hospitals industry includes operators licensed to provide diagnostic and medical treatment, in addition to monitoring services for inpatients suffering from mental illness or substance abuse disorders. These operators maintain inpatient beds and a staff of physicians. Facilities that emphasize counseling for mental health and substance abuse rather than medical treatment are not included in the industry (IBISWorld report 62322).

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid

key_trends: Consolidation will benefit hospitals and patients. Larger size brings increased bargaining power with suppliers, payers and complementary health services to patients.
COVID-19 changed attitudes on mental health. The healthcare crisis brought needed government focus and assistance to mental health and substance abuse treatments and facilities.

Technology aids but does not disrupt. Technology systems will augment administrative and communications functions, lowering costs, but will not replace the highly skilled labor needed to provide necessary services.

Government regulations control volatility. Continued government funding facilitates the ability to pay for those seeking services, increasing those seeking assistance, bolstering revenue and stemming volatility.

Patients face complex decisions when seeking help. In addition to doctor's recommendations, insurance coverage, the ability to pay out-of-pocket costs and the stigma surrounding hospitalization play a role in an individual's decision to seek hospital services.
Insurance determines bed utilization. With costs so steep, hospitals with insurance options for their clients will fill more beds.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Third-party payers do the heavy lifting. Commercial health plans include employer-sponsored insurance plans and insurance plans purchased through the insurance marketplace. Hospitals receive payments from insurers based on predetermined rates per diagnosis, per diem rates or on a fee-for-service basis, so coverage of inpatient psychiatric care will largely depend on each plan's specifics. Large group insurance plans are not mandated to offer coverage, but if available, they must be equal to benefits for general care. Typically, group insurance plans provide more comprehensive coverage than Medicaid or Medicare.

Medicare and Medicaid cover one-third of psychiatric admissions and use the inpatient psychiatric facility prospective payment system (IPF PPS) to reimburse for inpatient psychiatric care. IPF payments are adjusted yearly based on a market basket index.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most hospital revenue from inpatient psychiatric services stems from the patient's primary diagnosis. Referrals and hospitalizations flow from doctors' diagnosis of a disorder (e.g., anxiety disorders, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, drug detoxification and eating disorders).

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Societal trends aggravate mental health conditions
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Societal trends, including social media use, increased economic and social pressures and health shocks from COVID-19 have aggravated mental health conditions that can foster increased doctor visits and referrals for hospitalization.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Other Hospital Services Contribute a Small Amount of Revenue
demand_determinants.determinant_description: A negligible number of services involve acute, long-term care or assisted daily living with physical or mental rehabilitation. These services will generate a meager share of industry revenue in 2023. Patients needing physical rehabilitation are treated at a general or specialty hospital.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Donations, Grants and Gifts Make Up a Revenue Shortfall
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Revenue from investment income, government and private gifts, grants and charitable contributions is significant. Revenue from non-patient sources accounts for one-third of revenue in 2023.

business_locations.location_description: The West is home to fewer business locations than its share of the population, with California home to many establishments.

The Southeast region is home to one-third of business locations, while accounting for one-quarter of the population. Texas has the most establishments and is home to more than half of the region's share of business locations.

New England has the top three most rural states: Maine, Vermont and New Hampshire. New England region is not underserved. In contrast, the three rural states have 0.6% of establishments and 1.0% of the population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the federal government, CMS issues regulatory requirements for inpatient psychiatric hospitals that receive reimbursements from Medicare and Medicaid programs.
The Food & Drug Administration must first approve new pharmaceuticals and medical devices.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations
regulations_points.regulation_description: JCAHO is an independent nonprofit organization that evaluates and accredits healthcare organizations (including psychiatric hospital organizations) and programs.

These health reforms expanded access to insurance coverage and modified aspects of the commercial insurance market. The legislation changed the Medicaid and Medicare programs, CHIP and other parts of the healthcare system.

The Anti-Kickback Statute prohibits healthcare providers and others from directly or indirectly soliciting, receiving or offering any remuneration as an incentive or reward for referring, ordering or recommending referrals or services paid for by a government healthcare program.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Paul Wellstone and Pete Domenici Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Employer-sponsored group health plans must provide coverage that is equitable to other medical coverage.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Federal Mental Health Parity Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: This act prohibited the use of lifetime or annual limits on coverage under group health plans that are different for mental and somatic illnesses.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Concentration remains low nationally, despite mergers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Hospital services remain fragmented nationally. The four largest companies account for less than one-third of net revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include hospital beds, gowns, meals, medical equipment and supplies.
The increasing trend in purchases as a percentage of revenue indicates that profits are being eroded over time for psychiatric hospitals in the US.
Hospital facilities operate in a strict regulatory environment and face unavoidable legal and insurance expenses.

The nationwide shortage of nurses and medical support personnel has posed significant operating issues for psychiatric hospitals causing hospitals to offer higher wages and more comprehensive benefits to attract and retain personnel.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: New entrants will compete with hospitals that often have supply contracts with medical suppliers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low Rate of New Patent Technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low.
However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry.
The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated.

volatility_points.volatility_description: While bed shortages will differ across locations, unmet demand for services industry wide lead to full use of hospital facilities and ensure steady revenue.

Increased Medicaid and Medicare funding and insurance coverage balanced against the nature of the immediate need for services irrespective of economic downturns, has kept revenue growth steady and smooth.
